nodes.text: K-nearest neighbors (KNN) can be used to predict the presence of heart disease accurately from clinical and demographic patient data

Dataset contains clinical and demographic attributes (age, sex, chest pain type, resting blood pressure, cholesterol, fasting blood sugar, rest ECG, max heart rate, exercise angina, oldpeak, slope, ca, thal) and a binary target for heart disease
KNN algorithm configured using Euclidean distance, K set to 10, each experiment repeated three times and averaged
Preprocessing steps include feature selection, handling class imbalance with weighting strategies, and use of cross-validation to estimate performance
Exploratory visualization: histograms for numerical features and count plot showing more male than female patients diagnosed with heart disease
Confusion matrix computed with counts yielding accuracy = (38 + 45)/(38 + 10 + 7 + 45) = 83 percent
Observed model performance indicates that KNN achieves promising predictive performance (high accuracy and reported high AUC-ROC values) for heart disease detection
Feature importance analysis was used to enhance interpretability and to identify key factors contributing to heart disease risk

Related work shows multiple ML methods (decision trees, SVM, neural networks, random forest, ensemble methods) have been applied to heart disease prediction with reported high accuracies (examples: decision tree 93.19%, SVM 92.30%)
KNN limitations include computational expense at classification time, sensitivity to choice of K, and requirement for careful preprocessing (scaling, missing data handling)

Conclusion: KNN is a simple, adaptable, nonparametric tool that can support risk assessment, early detection, and personalized strategies for heart disease when applied to appropriate medical datasets
Evaluation metrics used include sensitivity, specificity, accuracy, and area under the receiver operating characteristic curve (AUC-ROC)
Model selection included measuring K-neighbors classifier scores across different K values and plotting score versus K to choose an appropriate K
Assumption: patient records are labelled correctly for presence or absence of heart disease and reflect relevant risk factors usable by supervised learning
